The examples below showcase R applications and analysis performed using Sparklyr. Analysis are conducted in [R Notebooks](http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com/r_notebooks.html) utilizing dplyr and machine learning functions. [flexdashboards](http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com/flexdashboard/index.html) and [Shiny Applications](http://shiny.rstudio.com) showcase interactive dashboards with active Spark connections.

## Analyzing 200 GB in R, Spark, and Shiny [![](images/examples/github-logo.png)](https://github.com/rstudio/sparkDemos/tree/master/prod/taxi-demo)

<!--html_preserve-->
<center>
<iframe src="https://drive.google.com/a/rstudio.com/file/d/0B4AYvf7e_RJQNERwYUVnV1Z5ejg/preview" width="640" height="480"></iframe>
</center>
<!--/html_preserve-->

This example builds off of Todd Schneiders analysis of NYC Taxi Data. For details visit [Todd's repo](https://github.com/toddwschneider/nyc-taxi-data). The original postgres tables (**200 GB**) were transferred to S3 and then loaded into Hive tables on Amazon EMR. The analysis was conducted in an R Notebook and includes a [Shiny Gadget](http://shiny.rstudio.com/articles/gadgets.html). 
<br>
<br> 

## End-to-End [![](images/examples/github-logo.png)](https://github.com/rstudio/sparkDemos/tree/master/prod/end-to-end-flights)

This example outlines an end-to-end analysis using Amazon EMR, Hive, and Sparklyr. An R Notebook runs a batch roll-up of the entire flights dataset  (**12 GB**) in Spark and saves a .Rdata file. An interactive flexdashboard loads the .Rdata file and visualizes the results of the Spark analyis. 

```{r, echo = FALSE}
examples("end-to-end")
```
